children.name: a very small amount of a substance
hardly any
children.definition: hardly/barely any /scarcely anyespecially British   almost none at all:
examples: ▪ Don’t forget to order some more paper for the copy machine - there’s barely any left.

children.name: hardly any water/money/time etc
examples: ▪ The ferns manage to grow with scarcely any sunlight.
▪ He was fifty years old and his hair still had hardly any gray in it.

children.name: very little
children.definition: a very small amount, usually so that there is not enough to be useful, to be important etc:
examples: ▪ There was no ink in the bottle and very little left in the pen.

children.name: very little water/money/time etc
examples: ▪ Fish contains very little fat.
▪ The area has a lot of deer, but very little water and not much open space.

children.name: almost no
children.definition: such a small amount that you can hardly see it, use it etc:
examples: almost no water/money/time
▪ Potatoes have almost no fat, but they’re very filling.
▪ He had a longish, plain face with a straight nose and almost no hair.
almost none
▪ ‘How much glue is left?’ ‘Almost none.’
almost none of something
▪ By the time the dentist had finished almost none of the existing tooth remained.

children.name: no ... to speak of
children.definition: if there is no rain, food, oil, etc to speak of, there is almost none and not enough to have any effect:
examples: ▪ There had been no rain to speak of for ten weeks and the garden was dying.

children.name: none to speak of
examples: ▪ There’s no fuel oil left - none to speak of, anyway.

children.name: trace
children.definition: an amount so small that it is very difficult to see:
examples: ▪ She had very little grey hair, with just a trace near the temples.

children.name: trace of
examples: ▪ Police found traces of blood on the killer’s shoes.
▪ Tests have revealed traces of poison in his food.

children.name: a small amount of a substance
a little bit
children.definition: alsoa bitespecially British   informal a small amount of something:
examples: ▪ You shouldn’t have given me so much toothpaste - I only needed a little bit.

children.name: a little bit of
examples: ▪ A bit of detergent should get that stain out of your collar.
▪ Save a little bit of the paint to do the trim.

children.name: a little
examples: ▪ This glue’s really strong - you only need to use a little.
a little water/money/time etc
▪ A little make-up would make her look so much more attractive.
▪ The garden could do with a little rain.
▪ Try putting a little oil on the hinge and see if it stops squeaking.
a little more/less
▪ If we all used a little less paper, we’d probably save a forest or two.
a little of
a small amount of a specific substance
▪ A little of the grease got on my skirt.

children.name: not much
children.definition: only a small amount of something - use this especially when you expect or need more:
examples: ▪ ‘How much paper is there in the printer?’ ‘Not much.’
not much water/money/time etc
▪ There’s not much light in this room, is there?
▪ It was very cold, but there wasn’t much snow on the ground.
not very much
▪ That’s not very much paint if you’re planning to paint the whole bedroom.
not much of
a small part of a specific substance
▪ You can use my shampoo but there’s not much of it left.

children.name: a small amount
children.definition: use this especially when it is a measured amount:
examples: ▪ Squeeze a small amount onto the palm of your hand and spread the gel evenly through your hair.

children.name: a small amount of
examples: ▪ Stir-fry the vegetables in a small amount of oil.
▪ Even a small amount of the drug can be detected in the test.
▪ Small amounts of radiation were found on their clothing.

children.name: in small amounts
examples: ▪ Fluorine is present in small amounts on Mars.

children.name: trickle
children.definition: a small amount of a liquid, flowing out of something:
examples: ▪ Because of the drought, the river has become little more than a trickle.

children.name: trickle of
examples: ▪ There was a trickle of blood coming from the corner of his mouth.

children.name: dab
children.definition: a small amount of a liquid, cream, or powder which has been put onto a surface with something such as a brush or with the fingers:
examples: ▪ Can I use some of your perfume? I just want to put a dab on my wrist.

children.name: dab of
examples: ▪ She put a dab of ointment on the cut.
▪ The car just needs a couple of dabs of paint here and there, and it’ll be fine.

children.name: low
children.definition: if something is low in fat, sugar, salt etc, it contains very little fat, sugar etc:

children.name: low in
examples: ▪ The casserole is low in calories and fat.
▪ These new industrial cleaners are much lower in ammonia and other dangerous chemicals than before.

children.name: low-fat/-sugar/-cholesterol etc
examples: ▪ He’s been on a low-cholesterol diet since his heart attack.

children.name: low fat/sugar/cholesterol etc content
examples: ▪ Non-dairy toppings tend to have lower fat content than whipping cream.

children.name: when st or sb moves or changes a little
a little bit
children.definition: alsoa bitBritish   informal a little:
examples: ▪ Do you mind if I open the window a little bit.
▪ The centre of the town had changed a bit, but everything else was just as I remember it.
▪ Isn’t that house leaning a little bit to the right?

children.name: a little
examples: ▪ His work has improved a little since he began the special classes.
▪ Gas prices have fallen a little, but they are still much higher than last year.
▪ I could see that Mrs Ewing’s hand was trembling a little.

children.name: slightly
children.definition: a little, but not enough to be important or easy to notice:
examples: ▪ The temperature had risen slightly, but it was still very cold.
▪ He stood for a moment, his body swaying slightly.

children.name: not much
children.definition: only a little and not as much as you might have expected:
examples: ▪ Things haven’t changed much over the past few years.
▪ I added more memory to my computer, but its performance didn’t improve much.

children.name: a small amount of food or drink
very little
children.definition: a very small amount, usually so small that there is not enough to have an effect, be useful etc:
examples: ▪ We drink only occasionally, and even then very little.

children.name: very little water/meat/cake etc
examples: ▪ The soup is made with lots of vegetables but very little chicken.

children.name: very little of
examples: ▪ He ate very little of the food we had given him.

children.name: hardly/barely any
children.definition: also scarcely any especially British   almost none at all:
examples: ▪ I thought you liked my lasagne, but you’ve eaten hardly any.

children.name: hardly any water/meat/cake etc
examples: ▪ There’s barely any sugar in these cookies at all.
▪ Since his heart attack he’s eaten scarcely any red meat.

children.name: drop
children.definition: a small amount of something that you drink:
examples: ▪ ‘Do you take cream in your coffee?’ ‘Yes, just a drop, please.’
drop of
▪ Would you like a drop of soda in your whisky?
▪ He hasn’t had a drop of alcohol in 20 years.

children.name: pinch
children.definition: a small amount of a powder such as salt, flour etc which you can hold between your thumb and first finger:

children.name: pinch of
examples: ▪ Add a pinch of salt and half a cup of breadcrumbs.
▪ The stew normally tastes better with a pinch or two of dried herbs.

children.name: dash
children.definition: a very small amount of a liquid which is added to a drink or to food, usually in order to give it a stronger taste:

children.name: dash of
examples: ▪ It’s just vodka with orange juice and a dash of lime juice.
▪ The secret of this sauce is a couple of dashes of brandy added just at the end.

children.name: a little
examples: ▪ ‘Would you like some more coffee?’ ‘Just a little.’
a little water/meat/cake etc
▪ The next day Mark felt well enough to eat a little solid food.
▪ Would you like a little ice cream with your pie?
a little of
a small amount of a specific food, drink etc
▪ I think I’ll try a little of the casserole.
a little more/less
▪ If I were you I’d use a little less salt next time.

children.name: a little bit
children.definition: also a bit especially British   informal a small amount:
examples: ▪ ‘Can I serve you some soup?’ ‘Alright, but just a little bit.’
a little bit of
▪ He only ate a little bit of dinner and then went straight to bed.
▪ Would you like a bit of bacon with your eggs?
▪ We still have a little bit of cheese left, if you want it.
a (little) bit more/less
▪ Can I have a bit more red wine, please?

children.name: not much
children.definition: only a little - use this especially when you expect or need more:
examples: ▪ ‘How much cake do you want?’ ‘Not much, I’m on a diet.’
not much water/meat/cake etc
▪ There’s not much wine left, but I think we can each have a glass.
not much to eat/drink
▪ We need to do some shopping - there isn’t much to eat at home.
not very much
▪ You haven’t eaten very much. Do you feel okay?

children.name: a little
examples: ▪ Most people will give a little to charity if they are asked.
a little money/cash
▪ I have a little cash with me, but not enough to pay for both of us.
a little extra
▪ He earns a little extra by working on weekends.
a little over/under
a little more or less than an amount of money
▪ The car costs a little over $20,000.
a little more/less
▪ A private room costs a little more, but it’s worth it.

children.name: not much
children.definition: there is only a small amount of money, especially when you expect or need more:
examples: ▪ After paying rent he doesn’t have much left to buy food and pay bills.

children.name: not much money/cash
examples: ▪ Pete didn’t get much money when he sold his car.

children.name: not very much
examples: ▪ I don’t think he earns very much working at the bank.

children.name: very little
children.definition: a very small amount of money, so that there is not enough to have an effect:
examples: ▪ He spends very little on food.
▪ Considering they work so hard they’re paid very little.

children.name: very little money/cash
examples: ▪ When Maria lost her job she had very little money in savings.

children.name: next to nothing
children.definition: if the amount that something costs is next to nothing, it is extremely cheap:
examples: ▪ It costs next to nothing to go to an afternoon movie.
▪ The company’s profits climbed from next to nothing to $6 million in just two years.

children.name: nominal
children.definition: a nominal sum, charge, or payment is very small, because what is important is that something is paid, even if it is much less than would usually be paid:
examples: ▪ We are allowed to use the tennis courts for a nominal fee.

children.name: a nominal £1/$5 etc
examples: ▪ Tickets for the concert are a nominal $3 for students.

children.name: negligible
children.definition: an amount of money that is negligible is so small that it has no effect or is so small that it is not worth worrying about:
examples: ▪ The cost of maintaining the machine is negligible.
▪ Expenses for maintaining the investment fund are negligible - just half a percentage point of profit.

children.name: a drop in the ocean
children.definition: British /a drop in the bucket American   informal an amount is a drop in the ocean or a drop in the bucket when it seems very small compared with what is really needed:
examples: ▪ The United States pledge of $100 million to the rainforest fund is a drop in the ocean.
▪ Third World debt is so massive that recent pledges to reduce it are just a drop in the bucket.

children.name: paltry
children.definition: paltry sum/amount/pay/value etc such a small amount, sum etc that it is insulting to the people it is paid to:
examples: ▪ Club owners in Kansas City paid paltry wages to jazz musicians but gave them steady work.
▪ Last year workers were offered a paltry raise of only one percent.

children.name: a paltry £1/$5 etc
examples: ▪ Many of the workers in the factory received a paltry $2 a day.

children.name: derisory
children.definition: , especially written a derisory amount of money that you are offered or paid is so small that it is not worth considering seriously:
examples: ▪ Government increases in health expenditure are derisory.

children.name: a derisory £10/$100/10% etc
examples: ▪ The company’s profits increased 35%, but they’ve only offered a derisory 2.5% pay increase.

children.name: pittance
children.definition: an extremely small amount of money, especially when you think the people who are being paid it are being treated unfairly:
examples: ▪ They expect their staff to work hard, but the wages they pay are a pittance.

children.name: a mere/absolute pittance
examples: ▪ In the poorest parts of the country, children work 12-hour days for a mere pittance.

children.name: peanuts
children.definition: a surprisingly small amount of money - use this when you are comparing two prices or amounts:
examples: ▪ The workers get paid peanuts.
▪ He’s got so much money, $500 is just peanuts to him.

children.name: a small amount of st such as a feeling etc
a little
examples: ▪ ‘Do you speak French?’ ‘Just a little.’
a little trouble/patience/help etc
▪ We had a little difficulty finding the place but we got there in the end.
▪ You might need a little help getting started, but after that you should be fine.
a little of
▪ I can understand a little of the frustration he must be feeling.
a little more/less
▪ With a little more creativity they could have made the house look really nice.

children.name: a little bit
children.definition: also a bit especially British   informal a little:
examples: ▪ By now she was resisting him only a little bit.

children.name: a little bit of
examples: ▪ We had a little bit of trouble reading his handwriting.
▪ He brings a bit of experience and a lot of enthusiasm to the job.

children.name: a (little) bit more/less
examples: ▪ I think a bit more discipline is needed with these children.

children.name: not much
children.definition: only a little:
examples: ▪ Not much is known about her childhood.

children.name: not much trouble/patience/help etc
examples: ▪ He doesn’t have much experience of running a business.
▪ It was clear that not much thought had been put into the plan.

children.name: not very much
examples: ▪ We didn’t have very much understanding of the problem then.

children.name: a small amount of st
children.definition: a small amount of something  a little of something:
examples: ▪ There is a small amount of truth to what he says.
▪ Big improvements can be made with only a small amount of training and effort.

children.name: an element of st
children.definition: an element of something  if there is an element of some quality such as truth, danger, or violence in something, there is a small amount of it, but enough to be noticed:
examples: ▪ There is always an element of risk in mountain climbing.
▪ She tried to maintain an element of mystery in her relationships.
▪ Despite the agreement between the two countries, an element of uncertainty about the future remains.

children.name: a taste of power/happiness/fame etc
examples: a short experience that shows you what it is like to have power, fame, happiness etc:
▪ Alvin had had a brief taste of freedom and didn’t want to live with his parents again.
▪ She decided to become an actress after getting her first taste of fame in a local theatre production.

children.name: a very small amount of st such as a feeling, quality etc
very little
children.definition: a very small amount, so that there is not enough to have an effect, be useful, important etc:
examples: ▪ ‘How much do you know about computers?’ ‘Very little, I’m afraid.’
very little trouble/patience/help etc
▪ I had very little energy left.
▪ Changing the law will make very little difference.
▪ It makes very little sense for companies to maintain large inventories these days.

children.name: almost no
children.definition: such a small amount that you can hardly notice it:
examples: almost no trouble/patience/help etc
▪ Scientists have paid almost no attention to the new theory.
▪ She supports the bill although she admits it has almost no chance of being passed.
▪ The birth control campaign was begun 10 years ago but has had almost no impact in the rural areas.
almost none
▪ ‘What progress have you made on your research project?’ ‘Almost none.’

children.name: hardly/barely any
children.definition: also scarcely any especially British   almost none at all:
examples: ▪ She said she felt a lot of regret about leaving, but I felt hardly any at all.

children.name: hardly any trouble/patience/help etc
examples: ▪ They closed down the whole department with barely any notice to the staff.
▪ Mark is so lazy, he makes scarcely any effort to improve his work.

children.name: a touch/hint/trace of st
children.definition: a touch/hint/trace of something  a very small amount of something, that you almost do not notice:
examples: ▪ ‘Are you ready yet?’ asked Hazel, with a touch of irritation in her voice.
▪ For the first time a hint of tension had crept into their relationship.
▪ After speaking to her for awhile, he began to detect a trace of a Southern accent.

children.name: little
children.definition: a small amount, especially when you expect more:

children.name: little trouble/patience/help etc
examples: ▪ Little progress was made during the negotiations.
▪ The report offers little hope that the economy will improve any time soon.
▪ There seems to be little chance of him coming home for Christmas.

children.name: minimal
children.definition: a minimal amount of something is the smallest that is possible, so that it is not worth thinking or worrying about:
examples: ▪ The new operating technique involves minimal risk to patients.
▪ The impact of the sale on current employees should be minimal.
▪ The crew had very little experience and were given minimal safety training.

children.name: negligible
children.definition: a negligible amount of something is so small that it has almost no effect at all:
examples: ▪ The damage done to his property was negligible.
▪ Economists say raising the minimum wage would have a negligible effect on employment rates.
▪ The chances of a healthy adult contracting the disease are negligible.

children.name: next to nothing
children.definition: if you know, learn, say, hear etc next to nothing about something, then you know, learn etc very little about it:
examples: ▪ I learned next to nothing at school - the teachers were awful.
▪ My parents know next to nothing about the men I date.
